text: who's got that list of all the failed efforts to make python fast with a graveyard of compilers?

text: Depending on how you define ‘failed’, I don’t think many of them have done so. I don’t know of many that are no longer actively developed or don’t have users

text: Fair enough - there was a pretty hefty list of projects that just fell by the wayside that someone here posted a while ago.

text: nope. Same story with Numba, "ok so I can't use dictionary and can't use class...what am I writing again?  C?"  (ps: they are actively expanding the subset everyday)

elements.text: nope. Same story with Numba, "ok so I can't use dictionary and can't use class...what am I writing again?  C?"  (ps: they are actively expanding the subset everyday)

text: With Numba at least you don’t have to learn new syntax. There is lots of numerical code you can just slap `@jit` on and see a speed up.

elements.text: With Numba at least you don’t have to learn new syntax. There is lots of numerical code you can just slap
on and see a speed up.

text: only works for toys though, as real world python uses a lot of foreign subroutine and you can't mix them inside `@jit`

elements.text: only works for toys though, as real world python uses a lot of foreign subroutine and you can't mix them inside

text: I think saying it ‘only works for toys’ is going way too far, but yes. It (like all of these things) is not a composable solution
